source: # 1. Introduction
## Background

Melbourne has been on the most liveable city list for quite a few years.

I moved to Melbourne several years ago and decided to live here. I currently live in the south-east district in Melbourne and I find it very convenient with all these cafes, restaurants, gyms, banks, post offices, supermarkets around. 

Now I would like to invest in another property in Melbourne and I want to know which suburbs are similar to mine.
## Business Problem

Given the input of my interested suburbs (a pre-defined list), I need to cluster them based on the popular facility types of each suburb.

And the cluster with my current suburb in would be my top interest list.
# 2. Data
Firstly I define a list to store all my interested suburbs.

interested_suburbs = ['Moonee Ponds, VIC 3039',
                      'Ascot Vale, VIC 3032',
                      'Port Melbourne, VIC 3207',
                      'Docklands, VIC 3008',
                      'Parkville, VIC 3050',
                      'North Melbourne, VIC 3051',
                      'Richmond, VIC 3121',
                      'South Yarra, VIC 3141',
                      'Kew, VIC 3101',
                      'Toorak, VIC 3142',
                      'St Kilda, VIC 3182',
                      'Camberwell, VIC 3124',
                      'Malvern, VIC 3144',
                      'Caulfield, VIC 3162',
                      'Brighton, VIC 3186',
                      'Glen Iris, VIC 3146',
                      'Mount Waverley, VIC 3149',
                      'Boronia, VIC 3155',
                      'Keysborough, VIC 3173',
                      'Springvale, VIC 3171',
                      'Oakleigh, VIC 3166',
                      'Ashwood, VIC 3147',
                      'Burwood, VIC 3125',
                      'Carnegie, VIC 3163']

Then I will use Foursquare API to explore venue list of each suburb and transform the data into a dataframe.

I will use one suburb as an example and repeat the method using a for-loop in later section.
## Import Libraries

import requests # library to handle requests
import pandas as pd # library for data analsysis
import numpy as np # library to handle data in a vectorized manner
import random # library for random number generation


!pip install geopy
from geopy.geocoders import Nominatim # module to convert an address into latitude and longitude values

# libraries for displaying images
from IPython.display import Image 
from IPython.core.display import HTML 
    
# tranforming json file into a pandas dataframe library
from pandas.io.json import json_normalize


! pip install folium==0.5.0
import folium # plotting library

print('Folium installed')
print('Libraries imported.')
## Define Foursquare Credentials and Version

CLIENT_ID = 'D5CVWEKDS20W3NKL3SU3ZTLT0NYCFPEDEPR3C2MZM1S2N4Z1' # your Foursquare ID
CLIENT_SECRET = 'QCTRRVTE0P4VFB2HPZWQ251S53GUEGO5QIV1SSVDCZUTUHVY' # your Foursquare Secret
VERSION = '20180604'
LIMIT = 10000
radius = 5000
print('Your credentails:')
print('CLIENT_ID: ' + CLIENT_ID)
print('CLIENT_SECRET:' + CLIENT_SECRET)
## Try to Generate ONE Latitude & Longitide

address = 'Melbourne City, VIC 3000'

geolocator = Nominatim(user_agent="foursquare_agent")
location = geolocator.geocode(address)
latitude = location.latitude
longitude = location.longitude
print(latitude, longitude)
## Try ONE Call Using Foursquare API and Transform the Result Into Dataframe

# i want to know places around previous address within radius 
radius = 5000

url = 'https://api.foursquare.com/v2/venues/explore?&client_id={}&client_secret={}&v={}&ll={},{}&radius={}&limit={}'.format(
        CLIENT_ID, 
        CLIENT_SECRET, 
        VERSION, 
        latitude, 
        longitude, 
        radius, 
        LIMIT)

# 3. Methodology

For my interested suburbs, I will firstly repeat the above data section for all suburbs in my interested suburb list. I will append the dataframe to my previous dataframe.

Then I will make category a unique list, and create dummy variables for these unique categories.

Then I will analyse each suburb by getting the most frequent categories. And finally I will cluster the suburbs according to most frequent categories.

i = 0

for x in interested_suburbs:
    address = interested_suburbs[i]
    
    geolocator = Nominatim(user_agent="foursquare_agent")
    location = geolocator.geocode(address)
    latitude = location.latitude
    longitude = location.longitude

    url = 'https://api.foursquare.com/v2/venues/explore?&client_id={}&client_secret={}&v={}&ll={},{}&radius={}&limit={}'.format(
        CLIENT_ID, 
        CLIENT_SECRET, 
        VERSION, 
        latitude, 
        longitude, 
        radius, 
        LIMIT)
    
    results = requests.get(url).json()
    
    # assign relevant part of JSON to venues
    venues = results['response']['groups'][0]['items']

    # tranform venues into a dataframe
    temp = pd.json_normalize(venues)
    temp = temp.rename(columns={"venue.id": "venue_id", "venue.categories": "details", "venue.location.lat": "lat", "venue.location.lng": "lng", "venue.name": "category", "venue.location.city": "suburb"})
    temp = temp[['venue_id','lat','lng','category','suburb','details']]
    temp['suburb'] = address
    
    i = i + 1
    
    dataframe = dataframe.append(temp, ignore_index=True)

dataframe

# one hot encoding
df = pd.get_dummies(dataframe[['category']], prefix="", prefix_sep="")

# add suburb column back to dataframe
df['suburb'] = dataframe['suburb'] 

# move neighborhood column to the first column
fixed_columns = [df.columns[-1]] + list(df.columns[:-1])
df = df[fixed_columns]

df

# group rows by suburb and by taking the mean of the frequency of occurrence of each category
df = df.groupby('suburb').mean().reset_index()

df

# print each suburb along with the top 5 most common venues
num_top_venues = 5

for q in df['suburb']:
    print("----"+q+"----")
    temp = df[df['suburb'] == q].T.reset_index()
    temp.columns = ['category','frequency']
    temp = temp.iloc[1:]
    temp['frequency'] = temp['frequency'].astype(float)
    temp = temp.round({'frequency': 2})
    print(temp.sort_values('frequency', ascending=False).reset_index(drop=True).head(num_top_venues))
    print('\n')
## Suburb Clustering Using K-Means

# Matplotlib and associated plotting modules
import matplotlib.cm as cm
import matplotlib.colors as colors

# import k-means from clustering stage
from sklearn.cluster import KMeans

#!conda install -c conda-forge folium=0.5.0 --yes # uncomment this line if you haven't completed the Foursquare API lab
import folium # map rendering library

print('Libraries imported.')

def return_most_common_category(row, num_top_category):
    row_categories = row.iloc[1:]
    row_categories_sorted = row_categories.sort_values(ascending=False)
    
    return row_categories_sorted.index.values[0:num_top_category]

num_top_category = 10

indicators = ['st', 'nd', 'rd']

# create columns according to number of top venues
columns = ['suburb']
for ind in np.arange(num_top_category):
    try:
        columns.append('{}{} Most Common Venue'.format(ind+1, indicators[ind]))
    except:
        columns.append('{}th Most Common Venue'.format(ind+1))

# create a new dataframe
newdf = pd.DataFrame(columns=columns)
newdf['suburb'] = df['suburb']

for ind in np.arange(df.shape[0]):
    newdf.iloc[ind, 1:] = return_most_common_category(df.iloc[ind, :], num_top_category)

newdf

# set number of clusters
kclusters = 5

df = df.drop('suburb', 1)

# run k-means clustering
kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=kclusters, random_state=0).fit(df)

# check cluster labels generated for each row in the dataframe
kmeans.labels_[0:10]

# 5. Discussion

My current suburb is in 'final0' group, and the other suburbs in the 'final0' group are indeed similar to my current suburb. So it confirms my pre-judgement and now I can make decision with more confidence level.

Further to this, I think this method can be applied to other cities which I totally have no knowledge about.
# 6. Conclusion

This simple model can cluster different suburbs, so that user can get some brief idea about the similarity of different suburbs.

This model can be improved later by picking up venues in a more detailed level (dining, school, hospital, etc.), and make it a separate input parameter to the model.
